Dear Ms. Gillies:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 5/18/17.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MSA) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the
previous corrective action plan was ineffective.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or a
combination thereof.
1 of 8 social services workers was out of ratio.
This is a repeat violation cited during the agency’s 2016 Renewal Inspection
with a CAP accepted on 6/30/16.
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
The Foster Care Worker indicated in the Safety Screen for Relative 1 that the home
had beds for everyone when in fact the foster child did not have a bed. The agency
indicated that a bed was being purchased.
The Special Evaluation (SE) for Foster Parent 1 was very poorly written and the
timeline was not clear. The SE was initiated on 3/22/17 but the agency became
aware of the issue on 3/10/17. The contacts listed in the report were from other
workers and had occurred prior to the start of the investigation. Foster Parent 1 was
interviewed a month after the complaint came in.
The Supervisor approved both of the above reports despite the errors.
.
R 400.12319 Substitute care policy.
An agency's substitute care policy shall, at a minimum, contain
provisions for all of the following:
(a) Qualifications for substitute caregivers, consistent with
the requirements of 1973 PA 116 and child care licensing
4

rules.
1 of 3 foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that the required
substitute care clearances were completed.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(a) All changes to the factual information contained in the
initial evaluation and subsequent renewal evaluations.
1 of 3 foster home reevaluations reviewed did not have the correct list of household
members.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined
by observation of, and interviews with, each member of the
household and each social service worker who has had
children placed in the home during the last licensing period.
1 of 3 foster home reevaluations reviewed did not indicate that the worker
interviewed the youth or anyone in the home other than the Foster Parents.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to
accept the foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the
evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the
evaluation is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
5

(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing
transaction record documents from the certifying
agency.
(i) A copy of all special evaluations completed during the
last 2 years.
(a) 2 of 3 borrowed bed files did not have documentation of the certifying agency
approval.
(a-i) 1 of 3 borrowed bed files did not have any borrowed bed documentation.
This is a repeat violation cited during the agency’s 2016 Renewal

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's

prescribed by the department.
1 of 1 Special evaluation reviewed was not sent to DCWL until 12 days after the

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the

(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as

than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
1 of 1 Special evaluation was initiated 12 days after the agency was informed there

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.

(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary

R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
(a-j) 1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have documentation that the foster
parent was provided with the required information in 2 of the youth’s 6 changes in
placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(4) An agency shall place service plans in the case record, give
a copy to and review the plans with foster parents. The agency
shall inform the foster parent that the information in the plan and
any other information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.

in MiSACWIS but the report had not been saved or uploaded in MiSACWIS. There
was also no hard copy in the file.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there

DHHS shall ensure that informed consent is obtained and

informed consent must be obtained in accordance with the
“Informed Consent” section contained in DHHS Policy FOM

1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have the correct medication consents.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
SRM 200 CHRI Access to Authorized Individuals
General
All personnel requiring access to CW-CHRI must first be
deemed an authorized personnel. Authorized personnel are
individuals that are responsible for the licensing or approval of
foster and adoptive parents, clerical, and managerial staff who
support these functions and auditors/other vendors who have
been approved by MSP to view CW-CHRI. Prior to access of
CW-CHRI, authorized personnel must receive/complete the
following items and have them filed in his/her personnel record:
• ICHAT results.
• Successful completion of Security and Awareness training.
Note: Authorized personnel access is denied if the individual
has ever had a felony of any kind, no matter when it occurred.
8

Of the 5 employees who view CHRI, none of them had documentation of the training
at the time of the on-site inspection. After the on-site 2 of the 5 employees
completed the training.
The agency was not in compliance with CHRI storage and disposal requirements.
DHHS Policy Dental Examination
FOM 801
Dental examinations are required for children 3 years of age
and older, as follows:
• A dental examination within six months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination shall be completed
not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a foster care
out-of-home placement.
• A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every 12
months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
• Children entering foster care under 3 years of age must have
an initial dental exam within three months of his/her third
birthday.
1 of 6 foster care files reviewed had a late dental exam.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver.
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
2 of 22 service plans and PATP’s reviewed did not have the required signatures.
 1 of the 2 did not have a signature page uploaded into MiSACWIS nor was
there a hard copy in the file.
 1 of the 2 had the foster parent signature almost 8 months after the report
date.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
FOM 722-6H PACEMENT
First Two Months After Initial Placement or a Placement
Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
9

per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face
contact with the child must take place within five business days
from the date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within
five business days of the date of the placement move. At least
one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location. Each contact must include a private
meeting between the child and the caseworker. Note: A month
is defined as 30 calendar days, unless otherwise specified.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child each calendar month. At least one contact each
calendar month must take place at the child’s placement
location. Each contact must include a private meeting between
the child and the case-worker.
4 of 8 foster care files reviewed did not have all the required worker/child visits:
 1 of the 4 did not have a visit documented in May of 2017 nor was there a
second visit in the second month after a placement change.
 1 of the 4 did not have a visit documented in October of 2016.
 1 of the 4 indicated the first visit to the child in out of home care documented
as 7 days after case assignment.
 1 of the 4 did not have documented visits with the foster care worker between
4/23/16 and 6/15/16 as well as 6/17/16 to 10/11/16.
This is a repeat violation cited during the agency’s 2016 Renewal Inspection
with a CAP accepted on 6/30/16.
DHHS Policy Required Information in an Adoption Assessment
ADM 300
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be completed
by the adoption worker and approved by the adoption
supervisor within 45 calendar days of case acceptance….
3 of 4 adoption assessments reviewed were completed late.
 1 of the 3 was 18 days late
 1 of the 3 was 40 days late
 1 of the 3 was 44 days late
This is a repeat violation cited during the agency’s 2016 Renewal Inspection
with a CAP accepted on 6/30/16.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
10

 Use the new template for the Agency Assessment and have it submitted to
the consultant prior to the on-site visit.
 Make sure all employees are entering training hours into LMS and that the
supervisor is approving and verifying those hours.
 Put Relative Safety Screens in the child’s file as well as the providers file.
 Adoption orientation should be done before each adoption not just at
licensure.
 If unsure of recommendation for an adoption assessment indicate this in the
assessment and submit it rather than waiting to hear from MCI (or other
parties) and having a late assessment.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first Corrective Action Plan (CAP) was approved on 6/30/16 and addressed the
following violations:
 R 400.12205 Required staff for staff being over in case load sizes.
 R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities due to an agency assessment not being
submitted.
 R 400.12209 Orientation and training was cited because 2 new employees did
not have documentation that they received orientation.
 R 400.12312 Foster parent training was cited due to a foster parent not having
the required hours of training.
 R 400.12324 Reevaluation due to a reevaluation being completed late and not
having all the necessary information.
 R 400.12326 Borrowed home because the agency had no0t endorsed the reports
submitted by the certifying agency.
 R 400.12505 Supervision was cited because Independent Living files did not
have all required visits documented.
 MSA VII A 5 Assessments and Service Plans because of a lack of signatures.
 MSA VIII B 3 Medical Files due to incorrect information on the medical passport.
 MSA VIII D 2 Foster and Adoptive Home Recruitment, Retention, and
Support was cited because the agency did not submit a plan.
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-8 Supervisor Signature on ISP due to a supervisor
signing the report late.
11

 DHHS Policy FOM 722-8C Required Participation of Foster Parents in the
Development of Service Plans due to missing foster parent signatures.
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H Home Visit due to missing visits.
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-
OF-HOME PLACEMENT due to a missing second visit in the second month of
placement.
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H Unannounced Home Visit due to missing
unannounced visits.
 DHHS Policy ADM 300 Required Information in an Adoption Assessment
because CAA’s were completed late.
 DHS Policy ADM 980 Closing due to a missing closing summary.
 DHS Policy ADM 980 Closing Letter because of a missing closing letter.
The number of violations and repeat violations has decreased significantly this year.
This indicates the agency’s corrective action plans are working. Some adjusting of
individual corrective actions may be necessary to gain full compliance.
Special Investigation 2016C0103029 was initiated when it was alleged that a Foster
Child was staying with an unlicensed caregiver when she was supposed to be in a
licensed foster home. It was found that the unlicensed provider was only a substitute
care provider and the child was not living there. The agency was not found in violation
in regards to the allegation however an additional finding of R 400.12420 Updated
service plans was cited due to a lack of contacts in the case file. The agency
appropriately addressed the violation in a corrective action plan that was approved on
11/17/16.
Special Investigation 2017C0103012 was initiated when it was reported that the
agency did not address a notice to have a youth moved timely. It was found that the
worker on the case did not have the ability to complete her duties. The agency was
found in violation of R 400.12206 Staff qualifications with an additional finding of R
400.12204 Facilities due to the agency having on-going issues with internet, e-mail,
and fax systems. The agency appropriately addressed the violations and their
corrective action plan was approved on 3/17/17.
VII. SUMMARY OF ANALYST VISIT
Concerns about the agency were brought up by Foster Parent 2. Foster Parent 2’s
concerns had been brought up previously and addressed with the agency and the
Foster Parent.
Safety concerns brought up by the field analyst were addressed by the agency. A
missing heating vent cover and ceiling tile were replaced. The smoke detectors that
were indicated as missing were not actually missing but were hanging in a different
location. The previous detector holders remained on the wall making it look like there
were missing detectors.
12

Relative Placement 1 had concerns that were addressed with the agency, however
documentation in the file indicated the family was supplied with information about
relative home support. The children have since been removed from the home and
services are being sought for them.
The agency is being cited for misrepresenting that Relative 1 had enough beds for
everyone in the home. The agency indicated they were ordering a bed and because of
this they thought it was okay to indicate the home had enough beds.
Other concerns brought up about lack of support to foster/relative parents were
addressed with the agency during the exit conference.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes, rules, ISEP and contract requirements. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
